theText: Is he a friend of Crichton-Browne?5324 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 16 June 1997 Australia, was asked by Channel7 News on the evening of the strike why the unions were striking. What was his explanation? Secret ballots. They do not want secret ballots. They want to see these blokes stick their hands in the air because they know that, if they vote against them, they will cop a visit and some sort of retribution. They do not want these people to have their democratic right of voting without encumbrance. As complex as he tried to make the explanation, Tony Cook said nothing more. He just kept on about secret ballots. We knows why the secret ballots are not an option for the union, because they want to be able to manipulate and control their members by eyeballing them, knowing who does not do it, and turning up and standing around their families. The unionists have been very active in letters to the editor columns in this campaign by asking that, if the parliament thinks secret ballots should be mandatory for unions and workplaces, why they are not so for parliamentarians. Where is their logic? How do they arrive at such a ludicrous, unrelated suggestion? The fact of secret ballots is, alone, hardly a reason to react to the Western Australian Industrial Relations Amendment Bill in the way that some Western Australian workers were incited to react-the bill to which Kim Beazley is so vehemently opposed. I hope he gets his private member's bill up; I really hope he does. referred to by their electorate titles rather than by name. ran. The rest of the bill is also positively fair and reasonable. Another part of the bill that the ALP unionists held the state to ransom for was the point of political expenditure. Why should my wife, who is a schoolteacher and chooses to be a member of the Western Australian Schoolteachers' Union, have to compulsorily contribute her union dues to be used as a fund for the Australian Labor Party and eventually used against me at the next federal election? It is totally wrong to use the funds of conservative voters to vote against the people they want to support. The act now ensures that members of unions will be able to direct their political donations to the political party or candidate of their choice. They will be protected from having their moneys applied to political purposes without their consent. This is the type of legislation that the member for Brand is against. It is why he incites Western Australians and the ALP disciples to become abusive and aggressive, so that they smash down this House and smash down the Western Australian parliament. That is their only way of trying to make their point. I think you turn the public against you when you start smashing up the democratic institutions of Australia. No wonder the member for Brand is so frustrated! He has got the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) sitting in his dad's old seat-the safe Labor one that he really wanted. He tried to get it, but they would not let him have it. Somehow he has not got enough pull in Western

theText: I hope you do. At the last federal election I had no help, and we had the5326 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 16 June 1997 the seat of Swan. Why don't you resign your seat and contest against me? consolidation strategy which moves the budget from a deficit position to a $1.6 billion surplus. This is a budget for small business. The budget impacts on, and assists, those small business initiatives announced in the March budget last year. A small business innovation fund of $120 million to the Commonwealth to commercialise technology ideas, capital gains tax exemption on retirement, and simplification of record keeping are all benefits for small business as well as a single entry point and common licences to help small businesses when they are dealing with governments. What will complement those initiatives even further is the opposition's acceptance of the workplace relations exemption regulations, which propose to exempt small businesses. We can expect continued obstruction from the Labor Party. We know that you are trying to stop businesses with under 15 people from being exempt from the unfair dismissal provisions. I really hope that you continue to stop it, because I would love to go to a double dissolution on native title and the Wik decision, on the unfair dismissal provisions, and on work for the dole. I would increase my majority and I would be very happy to do so. We know that, as far as unfair dismissal goes, Labor originally supported this and recognised it as an incentive to employ younger people in particular. But this legislation is currently in the Senate where the ALP and the Democrats do not support anything unless there are millions of taxpayers' dollars attached to it. They want to throw money at it and, in this case, it is not going to happen. As I say, I hope it becomes a trigger. I do not for a moment deny that there are some unscrupulous employers-I mentioned this in the House today-who would unfairly dismiss staff. But, realistically, employers have nothing to gain by going through the lengthy selection process, spending time and money training new staff, allowing them to develop into productive employees and then dismissing them and doing it all over again. In the youth unemployment area, quite often you will try several people before you find a successful one. (Time expired) me they were taking the plunge and buying their first home. With home loan interest rates now below seven per cent, they decided it was too good an opportunity to miss. Just nine years ago, as a Brisbane city councillor, I had constituents crying over my desk that they could not pay their rates because under Labor their mortgage interest rate had rocketed to 17.5 per cent. Now, thanks to this budget and the 1996-97 budget, interest rates are at their lowest level since 1972. To most this means a cut in mortgage payments of around $292 a month-far more than any union-delivered wage increase. You do not have to have a degree in economics, or even a vague understanding of the finances of the nation, to recognise the impact on the community of these changes. This budget continues the economic groundwork established by this government with its first budget. Above all, we are paying off the massive $10 billion-plus debt left to Australians by the former Labor government. This budget also introduces a first for the people of

speaker: Mr Mcdougall (Griffith) (9.37 P.m.)
theText: Last week two of my young constituents toldMonday, 16 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5327 Australia: a savings rebate to encourage saving. A rebate of 15 per cent on up to $3,000 of savings, which includes personal superannuation contributions, will give people a motive and a profitable reason to save. Since this government was elected, we have seen a lowering of inflation. This is of benefit to all Australians, including independent retirees. When your income is limited or fixed, spiralling inflation means rising costs of goods and services while low inflation means more for your money. Anyone who does not understand this should try buying a cup of coffee in Tokyo, where you will not get change from $10, or take a trip to Zaire, where inflation is now running at 600 per cent. Four years ago, a traveller received three Zairean dollars for an Australian dollar. Today you get $162,000 Zairean dollars for one Australian dollar. Our cost of living is, in my opinion, still far too high. It is, again, a legacy of 13 years of Labor government. It is now obvious to even the most inexperienced punter that this budget is leading us well on the way to financial recovery and therefore to social recovery. Social recovery will also come with a change in attitude. After more than a decade of untargeted immigration, handouts to any group who knew how to make enough media noise and a second generation of people with no expectations of jobs, urgent and dramatic changes had to be made. Firstly, let us look at the emotive issue of immigration. Despite the claims that we are being discriminatory by making changes to the concessional family category, the feedback I am getting from my electorate of Griffith has indicated strong approval for this move. Our new course in family reunions is one which most other countries have always adopted, with a focus on immigrants who have skills. As much as we would like to be a country of plenty, the taxpayers of Australia are hurting and simply cannot afford to sponsor migrants who have to be supported for several years after their arrival. It is just as important for the families of immigrants that those who come to join them and live in our country also have jobs. When we came into office we inherited a migration program dominated by the family stream which represented almost 70 per cent of the program. The previous government had simply opened the gates. Little or no serious consideration had been given to the impact of entry of persons with low skill levels and little or no ability to speak English. A respected member of my Chinese business community expressed her concern at the number of Chinese who had trouble finding work and assimilating due to their inability to speak, read or write English. She also told me that she knew of immigrants who chose Australia simply because, as she said, 'It was the easiest country to get into'. This government is restoring balance and integrity to our immigration program. Our goal is to make life as easy as possible for those who make Australia their new home. Our measures are consistent with taking responsibility for not only the future of those immigrants who have settled here, but also the new arrivals. If this is being discriminatory, as the opposition so loudly proclaims, then I suggest that their concerns are more for votes than the well-being of this country. Our priority lies with the reunion of migrants entering as the spouses or children of Australians. Parents, brothers, sisters, aunts and uncles can apply on their own merits and if they qualify, will be welcomed. By introducing a two-year waiting period for social security benefits for migrants, we have redirected a substantial amount of welfare dollars into the community. 5328 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 16 June 1997 It must be noted that this government has a commitment to skilled and business migrants who, we all know, benefit the economy and create jobs for Australians. Those of my constituents who look closely at this government's employment program will see that we are not focussing on shuffling funds by moving people off the dole onto the endless and often pointless training schemes. This was the cycle for the unemployed as established by tilt; Keating government: off the dole to reduce the figures; onto a training scheme with a marginal chance of a job at the end, and then back on the dole. A young man who came to my electorate office to have his CV photocopied had done six courses during the year, including a six weeks course in panel beating. I ask this House: who would allow a person with just six weeks training to start knocking dents out of their car? I am not alone when I say that I get many calls from constituents complaining that they have a job available but cannot find anyone with enough basic skills. A local builder told me two weeks ago that he had more work than he could handle and desperately needed to hire another three carpenters. He said any good carpenter was as busy as he was. He was now having to knock back work because he could not find anyone experienced enough to hire. This brings us to the $265 million in this budget set aside for more than 100,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships for the next year. Employers cannot afford to train young people without assistance. This bill introduces a $1,500 completion payment for employers whose apprentice or trainee achieves Australian qualification framework level 3 competency. In other words, we are training young people in jobs. Then there is the work for the dole pilot scheme, with funding of $21 million. This is not a shuffle off the dole scheme; this is giving people on the dole the most important thing they can achieve-that is, a work ethic-while placing them with a team to work at a real job, one that is of value to the community and therefore of value to the participant. I do not need to remind anyone of the demoralising effect of being unemployed. This can lead to the belief that you are unemployable. We can and will tum this around with our school to work strategy which has already been piloted in Queensland with great success. We also have introduced our Green Corps program, which creates training for people in one of the most important areas-the environment. People joining the Green Corps are working alongside environmental specialists and learning skills that are vital not only to the future of this planet and our nation but vital to the immediate community in which they live. I remind the House of the $1.25 billion in this budget to fund the Natural Heritage Trust over six years. The government was opposed tooth and nail by the opposition and minor parties in establishing this fund-the largest restoration program for our environment. Besides its vital importance to restoring our rivers, vegetation and land, this massive injection of funds will create employment. This bill makes it clear that this government is establishing the environment for jobs and training for young people from the moment they leave school, not after they have spent years losing confidence as they queue for the dole. The opposition and many politically motivated groups in the community are demanding faster action in creating jobs. This government will not create illusory jobs. This government is establishing a sound foundation for industry to create jobs-real jobs with lasting benefits. If the previous government looks at its own track record in my electorate of Griffith, there is a major area where jobs could have been created but this has been ignored. Monday, 16 June 1997 MAIN COMMITIEE 5329 I take you back to when the federal government, in consultation with the state and local government in Brisbane, set about upgrading Brisbane Airport and the Brisbane port. The port, at great expense, was moved to the mouth of the river at Fisherman's Island. The federal government committed funds to these two major projects, as well as funding for a national gauge rail line running from Acacia Ridge to the port. This was completed in November 1994. This grand plan was known as the gateway strategic plan, an initiative by the then Liberal Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Sallyanne Atkinson. This was a plan for industry along the Brisbane River from Colmslie to Moreton Bay. The region along the northern corner of my electorate is well-positioned to take advantage of this strategy and we looked to receive major investment from the commercial and industry sectors. Industry would create not only construction jobs but long-term employment. After exhaustive public consultation a regional strategic plan known as SEQ 2001 was evolved, which included the gateway strategic plan. I point out all of this because it shows just how much work and planning went into creating the infrastructure to encourage industry in the suburbs of Colmslie, Cannon Hill, Murarrie and Gibson Island, all of which are in my electorate. This strategic plan has gone into stagnation. I look at the rail line, the port, the airport and the arterial road, and ask the same question as my constituents: what happened to the promised jobs? I can tell them what happened at least to the last 200 which were promised by BHP. Last year the Brisbane City Council refused approval for BHP to establish a $160 million steel plant right in the heart of the area earmarked for such industry. I investigated the project. It fulfilled all criteria. It was knocked back purely for political expediency-and with it went 200 construction jobs and over 70 permanent jobs. With signals like that from Labor's Brisbane City Council, it is no wonder industries pack up and leave Australia, taking their jobs with them. This government has shown, with its first and now with its second budget, that we pay our bills before we throw taxpayers' money around for political gain. The changes created by this budget are establishing a sound foundation for Australia to redirect its focus on work opportunities, to retrain young school leavers and to pave the way for employers to hire apprentices. This training is for jobs which exist. We are creating an environment for savings as this budget establishes for the first time a savings plan for all Australians. It is very easy to swing a cudgel to make holes in the budget strategy as laid down by this government, but the facts and figures are there. This government has stopped the endless flow of dollars from the pockets of Australians. By the end of this next term, John Howard will have put this country back in the black. But it is more than dollars in the bank-this government has a social policy to match. We are changing the attitudes of two generations brought up to believe that the government was an employer. We have set in motion aged care reforms to tackle the urgent, if not critical, need for reform in the nursing home sector. The opposition can rant and rave about the introduction of accommodation bonds, but they cannot alter the fact that the nursing home sector is in crisis. The Labor Party cannot deny that our senior citizens, who are in need of special care, have been ignored. The Labor Party cannot deny that our nursing homes are having trouble keeping afloat and that many are unable to provide adequate care and facilities for their residents. The Labor Party argues that we are not putting enough money into the nursing home sector. Funny about that; it had been busy taking it out. The Keating government reduced capital 5330 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 16 June 1997 funding to nursing homes from $200 million in 1989-90 to just over $10 million in its last year. We have not only introduced accommodation bonds as a capital funding program for nursing homes, but also increased the government subsidy for dementia care by 30 per cent. We have redirected funding for child-care assistance to increase the number of low-income families able to qualify for assistance from 19,000 to 51,000. There has been relative silence from the opposition on this budget reform, but I am not surprised. Under the previous government, non-working parents were receiving 50 hours of taxpayer funded child care per week. This has been reduced to 20 hours. We have acknowledged that non-working parents who are studying or looking for work do need child-care assistance, maybe for up to 50 hours a week, and we have also increased assistance for those using outside school hours care. This is a government which has produced a budget for economic and social growth, and I support this bill. Appropriation Bill (No.1) 1997-98, the 1997-98 budget, together with the estimates for the coming years. I would like to congratulate the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) and the Minister for Finance( Mr Fahey) for putting together a document that not only meets the requirements of our nation today but, more importantly, meets the requirements of our nation in the period leading up to the next millennium. This budget is clearly focused on improving Australia's savings record. It is clearly focuseu on providing a stable economy in which business can grow and in which business can develop. Up until now there has been a growing tendency in government budgets to focus on issues that seem to please the electorate as opposed to budgets that focus on issues that are good for the electorate. There is a fundamental difference, of course. It is easy to envisage the Treasurer coming down the flagpole of Parliament House every budget with a bag full of goodies like Santa Claus and delivering a lot of goodies to people in the electorates and to businesses. I will remind the House that North Sydney, in my electorate, is the third largest business district in Australia. I discussed the budget with some of the 36,000 small businesses in my electorate, which is a very large figure, and with many of my 125,000 constituents. I encountered a disappointing response in all those discussions and that was, 'What's in it for me'? What do I get out of the budget?'. I have called it the Santa Claus phenomenon. Santa Claus comes twice each year to the Australian people-once on 25 December and again when the federal budget is announced. We have to change that attitude. It is a very difficult change to incorporate into the Australian ethos. It is very difficult. It is difficult when you have the New South Wales Carr government promising to give the parents of every school kid a cheque for $50 at the beginning of the school year just because the kid turns up to school. It does not matter whether they go to Newington or whether they go to Mount Druitt High, they get a cheque for $50. It is classic middle class welfare. Even worse, the Keating government introduced the pregnancy benefit. if you like. Every woman who had a baby was to receive a cheque in the mail for $200, and that was meant to ease the pain. It was not means tested so, in effect, it was a new form of middle class welfare. My response to that is that we cannot have middle class welfare at a time when we are trying to change the attitude in Australia so that people must rely on themselves for their future and save for their future.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Hockey (North Sydney) (9.55 P.m.)
theText: It gives me great pleasure to speak on theMonday, 16 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5331 Too few Australians would be aware that every week 7.5 million Australians expect a Department of Social Security cheque. That includes age pensioners who are, of course, in many cases, deserving of their age pension. That is 1.673 million people. In addition to that there is family tax payment; farm household allowance; mature age allowance; mature age partner allowance; Newstart allowance; Newstart mature age allowance; parenting allowance; partner allowance; rehabilitation pension; sickness allowance; sole parent pension; special benefit; widow allowance; widow's pension; wife pension; youth training allowance; bereavement allowance; carer pension; child disability allowance; disability support pension; disability wage supplement; disadvantaged persons scheme; double orphan pension, and so on. When is it going to stop? When will people stop expecting that they are going to get some form of benefit? There are 7.5 million Australians who expect a Department of Social Security cheque. Not for one second would I deny those who need help a helping hand, not for one minute, not for a second, because if people deserve then they deserve it. But 7.5 million Australians are not deserving of Department of Social Security support. There are 7.2 million Australians that are paying taxation and of the total budget of $133 billion. $53.4 billion is spent on welfare. Over 40 per cent of the budget is spent on welfarehealth, $20.7 billion; education, $11 billion; defence, $10.4 billion; economic services, and that incorporates repayment of our national debt, $8.3 billion; general services covering administrative services and a range of functions in support of the other areas, $6 billion; and of course payments to the states, $17 billion. That payment to the states is supplemented by the states' own taxation system, which roughly accounts for $33 billion around Australia. So the total tax take around Australia is around $150 billion, of which one-third goes in welfare to 7.5 million Australians. I suppose what I am trying to say to the people in my electorate is that we should support the people that need a helping hand. That is, part of the most basic Liberal phenomena and theme in the 1990s has to be to support people that deserve a helping hand. In my electorate, there are people that can afford and are prepared to pay their way in the 1990s and in the years beyond. It is those sort of people that are starting to come to terms with the fact that we cannot expect to get middle class welfare. We cannot expect to get a whole range of schemes that are going to prop up business. I have got a simple message, particularly for big business and it is this. As soon as you start to develop a welfare mentality, we can almost give up the game, because you are meant to be the proponents of self sufficiency, you are meant to pride yourselves on making a buck, earning that buck, producing a buck and then making a profit out of it. If you start to cry out for business welfare then you are letting the side down and you are making yourselves not only nationally uncompetitive but more importantly internationally uncompetitive. It is that part of business welfare when you see significant business interest groups in the Sydney Morning Herald, in the Australian or in the Financial Review saying, 'What is in the budget for me? What did I get out of it'? I will tell you what you got out of it. You got something out of it that you never got in the late 1980s or in the early 1990s under the Labor party. You are getting a long-term stable economy. And what does that mean? That means low inflation, that means low interest rates and lower interest rates and it also means most importantly that you have got an economy that 5332 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 16 June 1997 is starting to grow and to improve its exportation particularly to the biggest consumer markets and the fastest growing consumer markets in Asia. In short, what does that mean for business? Businesses went through a very volatile period under the Labor Party in the late 1980s and early 1990s. They were sold a pup during the 1980s that a boom would continue forever. The Labor Party sold it. You saw Bob Hawke and Paul Keating arm in arm with the Alan Bonds and the Christopher Skases and the Russell Gowards and all the various players that were out there-the entrepreneurial godfathers of the Australian economy, arm in arm. And what happened? Those people that they were shaking hands with and being photographed with in their black tie suits went to the wall quite dramatically. We are still feeling the effects of that. The most serious effect of that was not the October 1987 crash. The most serious effect was not the movement of money out of equities into real estate. The most significant effect was that it blew the confidence of small business in Australia. We came into the 1990s following the credit squeeze instituted by Paul Keating when he was treasurer. We came into an environment with fairly high inflation, but the government was trying to rescue the economy and failing miserably with the net result that again small business seemed to suffer the brunt through high interest rates, uncompetitive inflation levels and significantly falling consumer confidence. The most significant table, which I seek leave to incorporate into my speech, is table El in the Commonwealth budget papers. Leave granted. the underlying balance of the Commonwealth from 1960-61 to 2000-2001. And 10 and behold, this extremely revealing document seems also to indicate the ebb and flow of the political fluctuations in Australia. What we saw throughout the 1960s was an underlying balance of a surplus between one and nearly four per cent of GOP. In the mid-1970s, the underlying balance suddenly went into a deficit. Suddenly, we were running deficits of around minus two per cent of GOP and, of course, that was the effect of the Whitlam expenditure years when, basically, underlying outlays jumped around five per cent of GOP and he increased expenditure by 25 per cent in three years. And we start to wonder why we still have not recovered from the Whitlam years. Of course, revenue did not follow it and Australia went into significant deficit. In the early 1980s, we managed to recover. We started to have a couple of surpluses but with the recession in the mid-1980s, we went back into a deficit and, of course, as revenue was booming in the late 1980s we went into a surplus again. That was primarily linked to the massive creation of false capital in the Australian economy and, of course, in the late 1980s and early 1990s Australia once again went into a deficit as a part of GOP and we have not actually recovered. In fact, this year the deficit will be around minus 1.3 per cent and in 199798, it will be 0.7 per cent. It will not be until 1998-99 that we will actually achieve a balance for the first time since 1990.
title: Represent Atives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Hockey
theText: It is the most revealing table in the entire budget because it gives a total5334 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 16 June 1997 What does this mean for business? Over the next few years we are going to try and create a stable environment for you to do business. There is no doubt that interest rates have to come down further. When small businesses are paying 9.5 per cent and we have an inflation rate of 1.5 per cent, you start to really recognise why they are not making the super profits that everyone expected. You start to really recognise why they are not employing more people because within our taxation system there are significant disincentives for people to employ other people because of payroll tax, the superannuation guarantee levy, and a whole range of other factors that make the oncosts of employing someone far too great for a business to cope with. So how do you get business to employ more people? How do you get business to start to generate its own expansion? It is simple: you start to make businesses profitable, and that is a partnership between the economy and the businessmen or the businesswomen themselves. In the first place, this budget focuses on the economy. It is saying that we want to give you the right indicators and the right environment so that you can start to take a calculated risk to expand your business. You are not going to have rapid increases in interest rates. We are going to start to give you lower interest rates for the longer term. The best indication of how successful we have been in this is the significant narrowing of the gap between the 10-year bonds of the US and the Australian lO-year bond benchmark to just under 60 basis points. That is the narrowest difference between the US lO-year bond and the Australian 10-year bond for many years. What does that mean? It means that international investors are starting to gain confidence in Australia. When they start to price our lO-year bonds at the same level, or close to the same level, as the US lO-year bonds, they are saying, 'Listen, Australia is actually a stable and growing economy to invest in and we have confidence in Australia.' What does that mean? The Governor of the Reserve Bank expressed it perfectly when he appeared before the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration. He said that there is growing confidence in the Australian economy and that at no time in Australia's history have home loans been more affordable or more accessible to the Australian people. That was a very significant comment. More importantly than that, the Governor of the Reserve Bank said that we have to get increased competition into small business lending. At the end of the day, banks are there to make a profit for their shareholders. We must recognise that. The banks' profit comes about through their making one loan, managed by three people, of $500 million to a major corporate customer, rather than making a multitude of small loans to small businesses-500 loans at $1 million each or 1,000 loans at $500,000 eachbecause the resources going into the cost of managing the loans and the possibility of business failure is far more significant with small business than it is with big business. Therefore, the banks will lend to a big business every day because it is easier and cheaper to manage than it is to lend to a small business. How do we create competition in that environment? Banks have to play their part, but we also need to look to other means. One of the Wallis inquiry recommendations-which I will not go into today-was that we should be looking at trying to improve competition in the banking sector in the provision of lending, particularly to small business. There is little doubt that through this budget we are providing the stable economy that Australians have been yearning for. We are concerned-and we should be concerned-about Monday, 16 June 1997 MAIN COMMITIEE 5335 wage growth. We should be concerned that there is not an outbreak of wage demands, that people are not going beyond the pale in terms of negotiating increases in salary over the next two to three years. I am very concerned about recent claims that Commonwealth Bank employees are looking to increase their remuneration by around seven per cent per annum. If that happens, rest assured that Australian businesses will suffer the pain. Even if it is offset by productivity improvements, the people who are going to suffer are the businesses that cannot make the profit to pay the salaries. There is only one way, in a low inflation environment, that they can meet the expectations of, essentially, their shareholders, and that is to start improving productivity to perhaps unreasonable levels. You can only do that by improving your equipment, looking for new markets and working out better industrial relations, or simply by retrenching people and getting people to work longer hours. Maybe that is one of the reasons why we had a very disappointing jobs outcome in the last month. Australian business needs to stop focusing on reducing its employment levels. It needs to focus on how it can become more profitable and, therefore, employ more people. I commend the bill to the House. It is a landmark bill. It puts in train the budget until the next millennium. It puts in train the basis upon which we are going to build a stable economy for Australian business. More importantly, we are building an environment in which the Australian people can continue to have confidence that we as a government are acting on behalf of all Australians, particularly Howard's battlers. They are the big beneficiaries of this budget through the various announcements that have come to pass. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later date. Leave granted; debate adjourned.
